Judge Overton, of St. Landry, proposed tho subjoined
resolutions, which were unanimously adopted:
Resolved, That the thanks of this Convention are hereby tendered to Ha
Excellency the Governor, and the members of the Legislature of Texas, fr I
the liberal and fraternal spirit in which they received our agn I
Buckner II. Payne, on his recent mission to the capital of that State.
Resolved, That, in the opinion of this Convention, additional energy will
be given to the progress of the railroad from New Orleans to the Sabine, h
the speedy passage of the charter recently, introduced into the Legislature of
Texas, granting a liberal appropriation of land by that State, while it will be
the means of hastening the commencement of the road across that State to tie
Rio Grande.
Resolved, That, in the opinion of this Convention, the aforesaid charte?
and grant of lands will insure the construction of the said railway across the
territory of Texas ; that it will be the means of concentrating the public n
upon that route as the great national highway to the Pacific, and that it w
determine the action of the General Government in continuing the road, am
constructing it across the continent.
Resolved, That the States of Louisiana and Texas, being equally interested
in this great public enterprise, ought so to unite their exertions and harmonise
their legislation, as to hasten its progress and promote its early completion.
Resolved, That a copy of these resolutions be transmitted to His Excellency, the Governor of Texas, with a request that they be laid before the
Senate and House of Representatives of the Legislature of that State.
The following resolution was then introduced by Mr-
Martin, of St. Landry, and adopted by acclamation:

discharged the delicate and onerous duties assigned to him since the aojoufl1
ment of this Convention in June last.
